percentage of distance in the platform quadrant. ro is the calculated receptor occupancy of alogabat for gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 from measured plasma concentrations at each dose.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003ca id=\"h4-9\" name=\"h4-9\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">3.9 combination with diazepam on rotarod performance in rats\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">classical benzodiazepines, such as diazepam, are known to induce sedation and ataxia, which can be measured by the rotarod task in rodents. the aim of this experiment was to determine whether alogabat affects rotarod performance when administered alone and, second, whether alogabat modulates the sedative/motor effect of diazepam on rotarod performance when given in combination. diazepam at 5&#x000a0;mg/kg i.p. significantly impaired rotarod performance. alogabat (3&#x02013;30&#x000a0;mg/kg p.o.) co-administered with diazepam did not worsen the effects of diazepam on rotarod performance (\u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5c\u003c/a>). alogabat administered alone at 30&#x000a0;mg/kg p.o. did not differ from vehicle-treated rats, corresponding to a calculated gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro level of 88% (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary table s5\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h4-10\" name=\"h4-10\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">3.10 evaluation of cognition in rats\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">since non-selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> pams, such as diazepam, have been shown to impair cognition (\u003ca href=\"#b5\">ballard et al., 2005\u003c/a>), the aim of the following experiments was to study the potential effects of acute administration of alogabat on cognition in rats. this included attention in the 5-csrt task and associative (fear) memory in cfc. we also assessed visual&#x02013;spatial memory (pal task) and attention (cpt) in a touchscreen system, which provides a translational approach for assessing cognition (\u003ca href=\"#b34\">hvoslef-eide et al., 2016\u003c/a>). chronic treatment with alogabat was also assessed on spatial learning and memory in the mwm.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">in the 5-csrt task, alogabat at 30&#x000a0;mg/kg induced a small but statistically significant reduction in percent correct (3%; within-subjects comparison; f(3,30) &#x0003d; 5.6, \u003cem>p\u003c/em> &#x0003c; 0.01; \u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5d\u003c/a>). however, alogabat did not impair attention in cpt (f(2,20) &#x0003d; 0.3; \u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5e\u003c/a>) or visual&#x02013;spatial memory in the pal task (f(2,22) &#x0003d; 2.6; \u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5f\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">in the cfc test, alogabat was administered before the acquisition session to determine whether there was an effect on learning the association between foot shock and the surrounding context. in the first experiment, alogabat impaired cfc at 10 and 30&#x000a0;mg/kg, corresponding to calculated gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro levels of 75% and 81% (f(2,24) &#x0003d; 10.99, \u003cem>p\u003c/em> &#x0003c; 0.001; \u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5g\u003c/a>). a second experiment was undertaken to explore lower doses, and it showed that alogabat did not significantly impair cfc at 1, 3, and 10&#x000a0;mg/kg (f(3,36) &#x0003d; 0.9; \u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5h\u003c/a>), corresponding to the calculated gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro levels of 35%, 56%, and 72%. this suggests that the dose of 10&#x000a0;mg/kg is approximately the threshold level for the impairment of cfc and is likely dependent on the level of ro achieved per subject.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">in the mwm test, chronic administration of alogabat at 10 and 30&#x000a0;mg/kg did not significantly impair the acquisition of the hidden platform position (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary figure s2\u003c/a>). twenty-four hours later, the platform was removed, and the rats were allowed to swim in the maze for 60&#x000a0;s (probe trial) to assess memory-retention of the platform position. the groups receiving vehicle [f(3,27) &#x0003d; 8, \u003cem>p\u003c/em> &#x0003c; 0.001] and 10&#x000a0;mg/kg [f(3,27) &#x0003d; 7, \u003cem>p\u003c/em> &#x0003c; 0.01] had learned the spatial position of the platform, as shown by their preference for the platform quadrant (\u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5i\u003c/a>). however, rats that received 30&#x000a0;mg/kg alogabat showed impaired spatial memory of the platform position during the probe trial [f(3,27) &#x0003d; 3, p &#x0003d; 0.08; \u003ca href=\"#f5\">figure 5i\u003c/a>], and gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro was estimated to be 79%. in summary, alogabat impaired context and spatial memory at gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro above 70%.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h5\" name=\"h5\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>4 discussion\u003c/h2>\u003ca id=\"h5-1\" name=\"h5-1\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.1 \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em> and \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> characterization of alogabat\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">alogabat was shown to be a potent and functionally selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor pam \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em>. the functional activity of alogabat was confirmed at native gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors in rat hippocampal slices. \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> binding experiments demonstrated dose-dependent target engagement of alogabat in rats and cntnap2\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup> mice. the highest specific binding was observed in the hippocampus, which is consistent with the known distribution of the gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor subtype in rodents (\u003ca href=\"#b54\">pirker et al., 2000\u003c/a>). phmri studies in rats demonstrated dose-dependent perfusion changes, indicating circuit modulation by alogabat. there were consistent changes in the neural activity pattern across dose groups, with modulation of neural activity in, among others, the medial prefrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, motor cortex, perirhinal cortex, nucleus accumbens shell, amygdala, hippocampus fimbria, and substantia nigra.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h5-2\" name=\"h5-2\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.2 eeg signature\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">acute administration of alogabat in rats induced an eeg signature characterized by a power decrease in theta and an increase in the beta frequency range, which was qualitatively similar to the eeg signature of non-selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> pams such as diazepam (\u003ca href=\"#b71\">van lier et al., 2004\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b72\">visser et al., 2003\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b22\">friedman et al., 1992\u003c/a>). the lower magnitude of induced eeg beta-band power by alogabat compared to diazepam is likely attributed to its &#x003b1;5-selectivity, resulting in an overall lower magnitude of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor modulation. this eeg signature of alogabat is qualitatively a mirror image of the eeg signature of basmisanil, a highly selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 negative allosteric modulator (nam), which we recently found to induce an increase in the theta power and a decrease in the beta-band eeg power in healthy volunteers (\u003ca href=\"#b31\">hipp et al., 2021\u003c/a>). furthermore, the eeg signature of alogabat is in agreement with the link between beta-band activity and single-nucleotide polymorphisms (snps) in gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor genes (\u003ca href=\"#b56\">porjesz et al., 2002\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b67\">smit et al., 2018\u003c/a>) and ndds (dup15q syndrome, as) involving gene copy number variations of \u003cem>gabrb3, gabra5\u003c/em>, and \u003cem>gabrg3\u003c/em> (\u003ca href=\"#b24\">frohlich et al., 2019a\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b25\">frohlich et al., 2019b\u003c/a>). gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor-related changes in beta-band activity are believed to reflect the modulation of recurrent excitatory&#x02013;inhibitory feedback loops in the cortical tissue (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">whittington et al., 2000\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b70\">traub and jefferys, 1999\u003c/a>). for the administered doses, the calculated receptor occupancies were in the range of 77%&#x02013;84% for &#x003b1;5-containing receptors and 22%&#x02013;34% for &#x003b1;1-containing receptors (with different pam effects (e\u003csub>max\u003c/sub>) at &#x003b1;5 vs. &#x003b1;1). thus, at the studied doses, alogabat has some effect on &#x003b1;1-containing receptors, and further work is needed to systematically study lower doses of alogabat, including those &#x0003c;70% ro without the impairment of cognition in wt rats, to confirm whether the modulation of &#x003b1;5-containing receptors alone is sufficient to induce the described eeg effect. nonetheless, eeg theta- and beta-band power are promising candidates for translational mechanistic biomarkers of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor function and could be used in the further development of alogabat.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h5-3\" name=\"h5-3\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.3 behavioral effects of alogabat in animal models relevant to asd\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">we assessed the effects of alogabat in two different mouse models relevant to asd, one phenotypic and one genetic. acute administration of alogabat significantly and dose-dependently attenuated excessive grooming, but not digging, behavior in btbr mice. sub-chronic administration of alogabat significantly attenuated elevated grooming behavior in cntnap2\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup> mice. efficacy in these different models was linked to gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro above 50%. despite initial findings of a transiently decreased activity in an open-field test, alogabat increased the activity of btbr mice and had no effect on the activity of cntnap2\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup> mice during the grooming test, supporting the specific effect of alogabat on repetitive grooming. we have tested additional compounds with similar properties, e.g., ro7015738, and have confirmed that gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 pams reduce repetitive behaviors in these mouse models (\u003ca href=\"#b10\">buettelmann et al., 2018\u003c/a>). these results align well with recently published data showing that gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor deficiency causes autism-like behaviors in mice, including increased grooming and reduced social contacts (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">zurek et al., 2016\u003c/a>), and with sh-053-2&#x02032;f-r-ch3, a gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 pam, which was recently shown to have positive effects on social and cognitive deficits in a rat model of autism (\u003ca href=\"#b68\">souza et al., 2024\u003c/a>). our data are valuable in providing information on the ro required for \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> effects on repetitive behavior. however, it should be noted that this effect may not directly translate to all individuals with asd as it is a heterogeneous disorder, whereas these mouse models exhibit specific genetic or phenotypic deficits.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h5-4\" name=\"h5-4\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.4 anticonvulsant effects of alogabat\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">it has been proposed that the reduction of gabaergic inhibitory activity results in hyperexcitability of minicolumn circuits, explaining some of the symptomatology observed in some ndds, including the high incidence of seizures and auditory&#x02013;tactile hypersensitivity (\u003ca href=\"#b60\">rubenstein and merzenich, 2003\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b26\">frye et al., 2016\u003c/a>). in the current study, we demonstrated that alogabat exhibits an anticonvulsant profile with activity comparable to the benzodiazepine drug class in acutely induced seizure models (electrical and chemical). alogabat had a small effect on seizures in the mes test, whereas in the ptz test, alogabat was shown to completely block seizures at calculated gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro &#x0003e;70%. since ptz is a gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> antagonist, this supports the assessment of alogabat for anticonvulsant activity in disorders where there is dysfunction of the gabaergic system. furthermore, in a separate eeg study, we observed that one out of eight rats had frequent spike-and-wave discharge (swd) activity, which was alleviated following treatment with alogabat (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary figures s3a&#x02013;s3c\u003c/a>; methods in \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary material\u003c/a>). to better understand the temporal dynamics of swd occurrence and the suppressing effect of alogabat, we performed a follow-up study on three additional rats that showed pronounced swd. both 3 and 10&#x000a0;mg/kg alogabat substantially reduced the number of swds within the first 3&#x000a0;h of recording, when the same rats showed increased swd numbers in the vehicle control condition (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary figures s3d&#x02013;s3f\u003c/a>), which corresponds to the calculated gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro level of 30%&#x02013;46% (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary table s6\u003c/a>). from a circuit perspective, the consensus is that such epileptic activity is generated by dysregulated thalamocortical circuitry, with abnormal interactions between reticular thalamic neurons and thalamic relay cells acting as the trigger and cortical circuits serving as the generator (\u003ca href=\"#b66\">sitnikova et al., 2023\u003c/a>). considering that in rats, &#x003b1;5-subunit-containing gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors are enriched in the cortex and hippocampus (\u003ca href=\"#b64\">serwanski et al., 2006\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b33\">hu et al., 2019\u003c/a>), mediating dendritic inhibition on pyramidal neurons (\u003ca href=\"#b2\">ali and thomson, 2008\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b62\">schulz et al., 2018\u003c/a>), we hypothesize that alogabat could suppress swd generation by enhancing the inhibition of cortical pyramidal neurons. however, more systematic work is required to confirm that alogabat can prevent swd activity.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h5-5\" name=\"h5-5\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">4.5 assessment of non-specific behavioral effects\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">non-selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> pams, such as diazepam and chlordiazepoxide, are effective anxiolytics in clinical use but have also been shown to impair cognition in rodents and humans. gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptors are believed to play a major role in cognition since they are predominantly expressed in the hippocampus in rats, where they regulate nmdar-dependent synaptic plasticity underlying learning and memory processes (\u003ca href=\"#b62\">schulz et al., 2018\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b23\">fritschy et al., 1997\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b63\">schulz et al., 2019\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b14\">davenport et al., 2021\u003c/a>). moreover, it has been proposed that gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> pams may induce memory impairment by modulating hippocampal function (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">mcnaughton and morris, 1987\u003c/a>). therefore, alogabat was evaluated in several rodent tests of cognition to determine whether a selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 pam would induce cognitive impairment following acute administration in rats. there was no effect of alogabat up to 70% gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro on cognition (visual&#x02013;spatial memory, attention, context fear conditioning, spatial learning, and memory). cognitive impairment was only observed at high doses (&#x0003e;70% ro) and supra-therapeutic levels of alogabat in associative (fear) learning (cfc) and spatial memory in the mwm in wildtype rats. the impairment at high doses is likely linked to the loss of selectivity toward gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> &#x003b1;1, &#x003b1;2, and &#x003b1;3 receptor subtypes (&#x003b1;1 ro was calculated as 19%&#x02013;25% at these doses; see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary table s6\u003c/a>). in addition to the loss of selectivity, we cannot exclude the possibility that these effects may be a consequence of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor saturation, i.e., excessive &#x003b1;5 activity in wildtype subjects may be detrimental. the cognitive impairment observed in wildtype rats may translate to healthy human subjects; however, our focus is on the effect of &#x003b1;5 pams in disease conditions with impaired gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> signaling and impaired cognition, where our hypothesis is that an &#x003b1;5 pam would have beneficial effects.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">alogabat had no effect on social approach/avoidance, the elevated plus maze, and the vogel conflict test in rats at ro levels up to 80% (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary figure s4\u003c/a> and methods in \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary material\u003c/a>), suggesting that alogabat does not exhibit an anxiolytic-like effect in rodents. this might be explained by the low expression of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 in the amygdala, a key node controlling anxiety-like behaviors. potential anxiolytic effects of alogabat in humans cannot be excluded as this receptor subtype is much more abundant in the human amygdala. since benzodiazepines, such as diazepam, are frequently used to treat anxiety and seizures in ndds, it was important to establish that alogabat at relevant therapeutic doses in mouse models did not worsen the sedative/motor-impairing effects of diazepam in the rotarod test. alogabat did not worsen diazepam-induced motor impairment; on the contrary, in combination, it reduced the motor impairments, which is more likely due to the more localized and precise inhibitory effect, counterbalancing the broader suppression of neuronal activity by diazepam, or due to lower intrinsic activity at &#x003b1;1 receptors compared to diazepam. we have previously shown that a gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 nam, which binds at the benzodiazepine binding site of the receptor, does not decrease the anxiolytic activity of chlordiazepoxide (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary figure s5\u003c/a>); therefore, it is unlikely that alogabat will interfere with the anxiolytic effect of the classical benzodiazepines.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h6\" name=\"h6\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>5 conclusion\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">multiple lines of evidence point to deficits in gabaergic signaling in epilepsy and ndds, such as asd and deletion as, with a prominent role attributed to gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors, including the gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor subtype. the current data for alogabat showed robust dose-dependent efficacy on repetitive behaviors in two disease-relevant mouse models and anti-seizure activity in the ptz rat model at gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 ro above 50%. our \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> occupancy measurements using the selective &#x003b1;5 tracer l-655,708 were highly valuable for understanding plasma and csf exposures (as a surrogate of free brain concentration) and their relationship to \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> effects. we observed that there was a 34-fold shift between the csf concentration of alogabat in the \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> occupancy study and that of alogabat \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em> binding data (ki value). the receptor occupancy of alogabat correlates well with pd effects (\u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> effects) and is consistent across the different studies/species (see \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary table s6\u003c/a>). this finding highlights the importance of using pet tracers in drug development.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">our data suggest that gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 pams may have potential benefits in individuals with autistic features and in conditions with clinical and nonclinical manifestations of cortical hyperexcitability and epilepsy. however, alogabat is unlikely to work across all ndds and should be utilized as a precision medicine to target a specific subgroup of the ndd population with deficient gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> pathway signaling, or specifically gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5. interestingly, recent data suggest that gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 pams may also have therapeutic potential in schizophrenia, alzheimer&#x02019;s disease, and depression (\u003ca href=\"#b53\">perez et al., 2023\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b39\">luscher et al., 2023\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b36\">koh et al., 2013\u003c/a>). with regard to the current status of alogabat, good-laboratory practice (glp) toxicology and safety pharmacology studies in rats and minipigs showed an overall benign safety profile, which supported its clinical investigations in phase-1 studies in healthy volunteers and phase-2 trials in asd and deletion as patients (nct03507569, nct03774576, nct03847987, nct04299464, nct05630066, and eudract&#x00023;2019-003524-20). the outcome of these studies, including pet, eeg, and effects on cognition, will be reported in the future.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h7\" name=\"h7\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>data availability statement\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">the original contributions presented in the study are included in the article/\u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary material\u003c/a>, further inquiries can be directed to the corresponding author.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h8\" Discussion
4.1 in vitro and in vivo characterization of alogabat alogabat was shown to be a potent and functionally selective gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptor pam in vitro . the functional activity of alogabat was confirmed at native gaba a receptors in rat hippocampal slices. in vivo binding experiments demonstrated dose-dependent target engagement of alogabat in rats and cntnap2 &#x02212;/&#x02212; mice. the highest specific binding was observed in the hippocampus, which is consistent with the known distribution of the gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptor subtype in rodents ( pirker et al., 2000 ). phmri studies in rats demonstrated dose-dependent perfusion changes, indicating circuit modulation by alogabat. there were consistent changes in the neural activity pattern across dose groups, with modulation of neural activity in, among others, the medial prefrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, motor cortex, perirhinal cortex, nucleus accumbens shell, amygdala, hippocampus fimbria, and substantia nigra. 4.2 eeg signature acute administration of alogabat in rats induced an eeg signature characterized by a power decrease in theta and an increase in the beta frequency range, which was qualitatively similar to the eeg signature of non-selective gaba a pams such as diazepam ( van lier et al., 2004 ; visser et al., 2003 ; friedman et al., 1992 ). the lower magnitude of induced eeg beta-band power by alogabat compared to diazepam is likely attributed to its &#x003b1;5-selectivity, resulting in an overall lower magnitude of gaba a receptor modulation. this eeg signature of alogabat is qualitatively a mirror image of the eeg signature of basmisanil, a highly selective gaba a -&#x003b1;5 negative allosteric modulator (nam), which we recently found to induce an increase in the theta power and a decrease in the beta-band eeg power in healthy volunteers ( hipp et al., 2021 ). furthermore, the eeg signature of alogabat is in agreement with the link between beta-band activity and single-nucleotide polymorphisms (snps) in gaba a receptor genes ( porjesz et al., 2002 ; smit et al., 2018 ) and ndds (dup15q syndrome, as) involving gene copy number variations of gabrb3, gabra5 , and gabrg3 ( frohlich et al., 2019a ; frohlich et al., 2019b ). gaba a receptor-related changes in beta-band activity are believed to reflect the modulation of recurrent excitatory&#x02013;inhibitory feedback loops in the cortical tissue ( whittington et al., 2000 ; traub and jefferys, 1999 ). for the administered doses, the calculated receptor occupancies were in the range of 77%&#x02013;84% for &#x003b1;5-containing receptors and 22%&#x02013;34% for &#x003b1;1-containing receptors (with different pam effects (e max ) at &#x003b1;5 vs. &#x003b1;1). thus, at the studied doses, alogabat has some effect on &#x003b1;1-containing receptors, and further work is needed to systematically study lower doses of alogabat, including those &#x0003c;70% ro without the impairment of cognition in wt rats, to confirm whether the modulation of &#x003b1;5-containing receptors alone is sufficient to induce the described eeg effect. nonetheless, eeg theta- and beta-band power are promising candidates for translational mechanistic biomarkers of gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptor function and could be used in the further development of alogabat. 4.3 behavioral effects of alogabat in animal models relevant to asd we assessed the effects of alogabat in two different mouse models relevant to asd, one phenotypic and one genetic. acute administration of alogabat significantly and dose-dependently attenuated excessive grooming, but not digging, behavior in btbr mice. sub-chronic administration of alogabat significantly attenuated elevated grooming behavior in cntnap2 &#x02212;/&#x02212; mice. efficacy in these different models was linked to gaba a -&#x003b1;5 ro above 50%. despite initial findings of a transiently decreased activity in an open-field test, alogabat increased the activity of btbr mice and had no effect on the activity of cntnap2 &#x02212;/&#x02212; mice during the grooming test, supporting the specific effect of alogabat on repetitive grooming. we have tested additional compounds with similar properties, e.g., ro7015738, and have confirmed that gaba a -&#x003b1;5 pams reduce repetitive behaviors in these mouse models ( buettelmann et al., 2018 ). these results align well with recently published data showing that gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptor deficiency causes autism-like behaviors in mice, including increased grooming and reduced social contacts ( zurek et al., 2016 ), and with sh-053-2&#x02032;f-r-ch3, a gaba a -&#x003b1;5 pam, which was recently shown to have positive effects on social and cognitive deficits in a rat model of autism ( souza et al., 2024 ). our data are valuable in providing information on the ro required for in vivo effects on repetitive behavior. however, it should be noted that this effect may not directly translate to all individuals with asd as it is a heterogeneous disorder, whereas these mouse models exhibit specific genetic or phenotypic deficits. 4.4 anticonvulsant effects of alogabat it has been proposed that the reduction of gabaergic inhibitory activity results in hyperexcitability of minicolumn circuits, explaining some of the symptomatology observed in some ndds, including the high incidence of seizures and auditory&#x02013;tactile hypersensitivity ( rubenstein and merzenich, 2003 ; frye et al., 2016 ). in the current study, we demonstrated that alogabat exhibits an anticonvulsant profile with activity comparable to the benzodiazepine drug class in acutely induced seizure models (electrical and chemical). alogabat had a small effect on seizures in the mes test, whereas in the ptz test, alogabat was shown to completely block seizures at calculated gaba a -&#x003b1;5 ro &#x0003e;70%. since ptz is a gaba a antagonist, this supports the assessment of alogabat for anticonvulsant activity in disorders where there is dysfunction of the gabaergic system. furthermore, in a separate eeg study, we observed that one out of eight rats had frequent spike-and-wave discharge (swd) activity, which was alleviated following treatment with alogabat (see supplementary figures s3a&#x02013;s3c ; methods in supplementary material ). to better understand the temporal dynamics of swd occurrence and the suppressing effect of alogabat, we performed a follow-up study on three additional rats that showed pronounced swd. both 3 and 10&#x000a0;mg/kg alogabat substantially reduced the number of swds within the first 3&#x000a0;h of recording, when the same rats showed increased swd numbers in the vehicle control condition (see supplementary figures s3d&#x02013;s3f ), which corresponds to the calculated gaba a -&#x003b1;5 ro level of 30%&#x02013;46% (see supplementary table s6 ). from a circuit perspective, the consensus is that such epileptic activity is generated by dysregulated thalamocortical circuitry, with abnormal interactions between reticular thalamic neurons and thalamic relay cells acting as the trigger and cortical circuits serving as the generator ( sitnikova et al., 2023 ). considering that in rats, &#x003b1;5-subunit-containing gaba a receptors are enriched in the cortex and hippocampus ( serwanski et al., 2006 ; hu et al., 2019 ), mediating dendritic inhibition on pyramidal neurons ( ali and thomson, 2008 ; schulz et al., 2018 ), we hypothesize that alogabat could suppress swd generation by enhancing the inhibition of cortical pyramidal neurons. however, more systematic work is required to confirm that alogabat can prevent swd activity. 4.5 assessment of non-specific behavioral effects non-selective gaba a pams, such as diazepam and chlordiazepoxide, are effective anxiolytics in clinical use but have also been shown to impair cognition in rodents and humans. gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptors are believed to play a major role in cognition since they are predominantly expressed in the hippocampus in rats, where they regulate nmdar-dependent synaptic plasticity underlying learning and memory processes ( schulz et al., 2018 ; fritschy et al., 1997 ; schulz et al., 2019 ; davenport et al., 2021 ). moreover, it has been proposed that gaba a pams may induce memory impairment by modulating hippocampal function ( mcnaughton and morris, 1987 ). therefore, alogabat was evaluated in several rodent tests of cognition to determine whether a selective gaba a -&#x003b1;5 pam would induce cognitive impairment following acute administration in rats. there was no effect of alogabat up to 70% gaba a -&#x003b1;5 ro on cognition (visual&#x02013;spatial memory, attention, context fear conditioning, spatial learning, and memory). cognitive impairment was only observed at high doses (&#x0003e;70% ro) and supra-therapeutic levels of alogabat in associative (fear) learning (cfc) and spatial memory in the mwm in wildtype rats. the impairment at high doses is likely linked to the loss of selectivity toward gaba a &#x003b1;1, &#x003b1;2, and &#x003b1;3 receptor subtypes (&#x003b1;1 ro was calculated as 19%&#x02013;25% at these doses; see supplementary table s6 ). in addition to the loss of selectivity, we cannot exclude the possibility that these effects may be a consequence of gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptor saturation, i.e., excessive &#x003b1;5 activity in wildtype subjects may be detrimental. the cognitive impairment observed in wildtype rats may translate to healthy human subjects; however, our focus is on the effect of &#x003b1;5 pams in disease conditions with impaired gaba a signaling and impaired cognition, where our hypothesis is that an &#x003b1;5 pam would have beneficial effects. alogabat had no effect on social approach/avoidance, the elevated plus maze, and the vogel conflict test in rats at ro levels up to 80% (see supplementary figure s4 and methods in supplementary material ), suggesting that alogabat does not exhibit an anxiolytic-like effect in rodents. this might be explained by the low expression of gaba a -&#x003b1;5 in the amygdala, a key node controlling anxiety-like behaviors. potential anxiolytic effects of alogabat in humans cannot be excluded as this receptor subtype is much more abundant in the human amygdala. since benzodiazepines, such as diazepam, are frequently used to treat anxiety and seizures in ndds, it was important to establish that alogabat at relevant therapeutic doses in mouse models did not worsen the sedative/motor-impairing effects of diazepam in the rotarod test. alogabat did not worsen diazepam-induced motor impairment; on the contrary, in combination, it reduced the motor impairments, which is more likely due to the more localized and precise inhibitory effect, counterbalancing the broader suppression of neuronal activity by diazepam, or due to lower intrinsic activity at &#x003b1;1 receptors compared to diazepam. we have previously shown that a gaba a -&#x003b1;5 nam, which binds at the benzodiazepine binding site of the receptor, does not decrease the anxiolytic activity of chlordiazepoxide (see supplementary figure s5 ); therefore, it is unlikely that alogabat will interfere with the anxiolytic effect of the classical benzodiazepines. 5 conclusion multiple lines of evidence point to deficits in gabaergic signaling in epilepsy and ndds, such as asd and deletion as, with a prominent role attributed to gaba a receptors, including the gaba a -&#x003b1;5 receptor subtype. the current data for alogabat showed robust dose-dependent efficacy on repetitive behaviors in two disease-relevant mouse models and anti-seizure activity in the ptz rat model at gaba a -&#x003b1;5 ro above 50%. our in vivo occupancy measurements using the selective &#x003b1;5 tracer l-655,708 were highly valuable for understanding plasma and csf exposures (as a surrogate of free brain concentration) and their relationship to in vivo effects. we observed that there was a 34-fold shift between the csf concentration of alogabat in the in vivo occupancy study and that of alogabat in vitro binding data (ki value). the receptor occupancy of alogabat correlates well with pd effects ( in vivo effects) and is consistent across the different studies/species (see supplementary table s6 ). this finding highlights the importance of using pet tracers in drug development. our data suggest that gaba a -&#x003b1;5 pams may have potential benefits in individuals with autistic features and in conditions with clinical and nonclinical manifestations of cortical hyperexcitability and epilepsy. however, alogabat is unlikely to work across all ndds and should be utilized as a precision medicine to target a specific subgroup of the ndd population with deficient gaba a pathway signaling, or specifically gaba a -&#x003b1;5. interestingly, recent data suggest that gaba a -&#x003b1;5 pams may also have therapeutic potential in schizophrenia, alzheimer&#x02019;s disease, and depression ( perez et al., 2023 ; luscher et al., 2023 ; koh et al., 2013 ). with regard to the current status of alogabat, good-laboratory practice (glp) toxicology and safety pharmacology studies in rats and minipigs showed an overall benign safety profile, which supported its clinical investigations in phase-1 studies in healthy volunteers and phase-2 trials in asd and deletion as patients (nct03507569, nct03774576, nct03847987, nct04299464, nct05630066, and eudract&#x00023;2019-003524-20). the outcome of these studies, including pet, eeg, and effects on cognition, will be reported in the future. data availability statement the original contributions presented in the study are included in the article/ supplementary material , further world's most cited pharmacology and pharmacy journal, advancing global pharmacological discoveries to prevent and treat human disease.","\u003cp>frontiers in pharmacology is an interdisciplinary journal that publishes research on the interactions between drugs and living beings to prevent and cure human disease.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>led by field chief editor heike wulff (university of california, davis, us), frontiers in pharmacology explores basic and clinical pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, pharmacy, and toxicology to clarify the fundamental processes of disease treatment and drug effects. indexed in pubmed central (pmc), scopus, web of science (scie), and the doaj, the journal welcomes academic, industrial, and clinical work focused on pharmacology.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>topics include, but are not limited to:\u003c/p>\n\u003cul>\n \u003cli>cardiovascular and smooth muscle pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>drug metabolism and transport\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>drugs outcomes research and policies\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>elsi in science and genetics\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>ethnopharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>experimental pharmacology and drug discovery\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>gastrointestinal and hepatic pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>inflammation pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>integrative and regenerative pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>neuropharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>obstetric and pediatric pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>pharmacoepidemiology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>pharmacology of anti-cancer drugs\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>pharmacology of infectious diseases\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>pharmacology of ion channels and channelopathies\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>predictive toxicology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>renal pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>respiratory pharmacology\u003c/li>\n \u003cli>translational pharmacology.\u003c/li>\n\u003c/ul>\n\n\u003cp>all submissions to the journal involving natural products, including plant extracts or preparations, must adhere to \u003ci>'the four pillars of ethnopharmacology'\u003c/i> to be considered for peer review, regardless of the specialty section, as a baseline standard for sample characterization. these are a set of mandatory guidelines designed to maintain the scientific, cultural, and ethical integrity of the journal, and describe what the leading journals in the field consider as the basic aspects of good research (full conphymp statement available \u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/pharmacology/articles/10.3389/fphar.2022.953205/full\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>, conphymp statement overview \u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/pharmacology/articles/10.3389/fphar.2023.1338710/full\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>, and ga-tool \u003ca href=\"https://ga-online.org/best-practice/\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>). please refer to the \u003ca href=\"https://assets.ctfassets.net/41vi7p4898pd/63dcrrxgncg4b1stfayeh8/1b87b9a742b0610ace5b19fd11f62359/four_pillars_ethnopharmacology_2025.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">full version\u003c/a> of these guidelines before submitting a manuscript to the journal.\u003c/p> \n\u003cp>to be considered for publication in frontiers in pharmacology, studies incorporating complementary or alternative medicine must be based on a set of data linked to local or traditional uses that can be evaluated pharmacologically. a clear and plausible set of pharmacological data must be generated in these studies. similarly, the journal endorses protocols including a minimum of 2 cell-lines in vitro as an evidential basis to demonstrate proposed anti-cancer effects in all relevant studies submitted to all specialty sections in the journal.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>isolated data mining studies using disproportionality analyses of databases containing spontaneously reported adverse events, frequently lead to misinterpretation due to various reporting biases, lack of structured control, and insufficient demographic details. presenting such analyses in isolation typically does not yield clinically actionable safety findings without the broader context of a comprehensive signal evaluation. to ensure rigor and relevance, all submissions to the journal must be complemented by a proper systematic review and/or thorough analyses of reported cases, and adhere to the readus-pv guidelines (\u003ca href=\"https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/the-reporting-of-a-disproportionality-analysis-for-drug-safety-signal-detection-using-individual-case-safety-reports-in-pharmacovigilance-readus-pv-development-and-statement/\" target=\"_blank\">the reporting of a disproportionality analysis for drug safety signal detection using individual case safety reports in pharmacovigilance\u003c/a>). authors are expected to ensure compliance with the corresponding \u003ca href=\"https://readus-statement.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/readus-checklist.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">checklist\u003c/a> before proceeding with submission to the journal. full publication of the readus-pv guidelines is available \u003ca href=\"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/pmc11116242/pdf/40264_2024_article_1421.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">here\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>frontiers’ journals require that manuscripts primarily comprising computational studies of public data, such as nhanes or mendelian randomization studies, must include appropriate validation. please refer to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/guidelines/policies-and-publication-ethics#standards-for-research-methodology:~:text=complaints%20and%20allegations.-,standards%20for%20research%20methodology,-experiments\">frontiers standards for research methodology policy\u003c/a>, for more information. manuscripts not adhering to these standards will not be considered.\u003cp>\n\n\u003cp>further unique criteria for the conception and review of submissions may apply, where appropriate, for individual specialty sections.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>the journal welcomes submissions that support and advance the \u003ca href=\"https://www.globalgoals.org/goals/\" target=\"_blank\">un sustainable development goals\u003c/a> (sdgs), notably the \u003ca href=\"https://www.globalgoals.org/goals/3-good-health-and-well-being/\" target=\"_blank\">sdg 3: good health and well-being\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>manuscripts that focus solely on clinical trials, patient management, or conventional therapies without a focus on pharmacological research are not suitable for publication in this journal. additionally, studies that are purely statistical or predictive in nature, without providing novel insights into pharmacological mechanisms or drug development, are not within the scope of this journal.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cp>frontiers in pharmacology is committed to advancing developments in the field of pharmacological discoveries by allowing unrestricted access to articles and communicating scientific knowledge to researchers and the public alike, to enable the scientific breakthroughs of the future.\u003c/p>\n\n\u003cb>\u003cp>ethics information\u003c/p>\u003c/b>\n\u003cp>research involving human subjects should comply with the ethical guidelines outlined in the \u003ca href= https://www.wma.net/policies-post/wma-declaration-of-helsinki/” target=”_blank”>world medical association’s declaration of helsinki\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>similarly, authors are required to specify the institutional and national standards adhered to for the care and use of laboratory animals. transparent and accurate reporting of animal studies is required, with references to guidelines such as \u003ca href=\"https://arriveguidelines.org/arrive-guidelines\" target=\"_blank\">arrive\u003c/a> and \u003ca pharmacology of alogabat: a novel gabaa-α5 positive allosteric modulator targeting neurodevelopmental disorders with impaired gabaa signaling","2025-06-18t08:27:15.000z","2025-05-09t23:15:40.000z","2025-07-21t00:00:00.000z","2025-10-21t02:34:53.269z","backgroundalterations in the gabaergic system contribute to the pathophysiology of neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism spectrum disorder (asd) and angelman syndrome (as), particularly in cases involving large deletions in the 15q11–13 region. positive modulation of gabaa-α5 receptors may provide a novel therapeutic approach without the typical side effects associated with non-selective gabaa positive allosteric modulators such as diazepam.methodsalogabat was assessed for binding and functional activity at gabaa-α5β3γ2 receptors in vitro and in electrophysiological studies using hippocampal slices. in vivo studies in rodents included receptor occupancy (ro) using a selective gabaa-α5 tracer (autoradiography), pharmacological mri, and electroencephalography (eeg). alogabat was evaluated for its effects on the repetitive behavior phenotype in btbr and contactin-associated protein-like 2 (cntnap2−/−) knockout mice, seizure models, cognitive performance in rats, and rotarod performance following combination treatment with diazepam.resultsalogabat is a potent positive allosteric modulator of gabaa-α5 receptors, with binding and functional selectivity. receptor occupancy studies provided direct proof of dose-dependent target engagement. functional circuit modulation was demonstrated by dose-dependent regional perfusion changes in pharmacological mri and changes in eeg theta- and beta-band power in rats. at >50% gabaa-α5 receptor occupancy, alogabat normalized elevated self-grooming behavior in both cntnap2−/− and btbr mice and exhibited antiepileptic activity in rats. alogabat did not impair cognition in wildtype rats at gabaa-α5 receptor occupancy up to 75%, although impairment occurred at higher doses, probably due to increased activity at other receptor subtypes and/or saturation of α5 receptors. alogabat did not worsen diazepam-induced impairment on the rotarod test.conclusionalogabat showed beneficial effects in mouse models relevant to neurodevelopmental disorders and anti-seizure activity at doses that did not produce cognitive, sedative, or motoric side effects.",{"id":523,"name":524},24,"original research",{"id":526,"name":19},18,[528,529,530,531,532,533,534,535],"biomarker","autism spectrum switzerland\u003c/li>\u003c/ul>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">\u003cb>background:\u003c/b> alterations in the gabaergic system contribute to the pathophysiology of neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism spectrum disorder (asd) and angelman syndrome (as), particularly in cases involving large deletions in the 15q11&#x02013;13 region. positive modulation of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptors may provide a novel therapeutic approach without the typical side effects associated with non-selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> positive allosteric modulators such as diazepam.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">\u003cb>methods:\u003c/b> alogabat was assessed for binding and functional activity at gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5&#x003b2;3&#x003b3;2 receptors \u003cem>in vitro\u003c/em> and in electrophysiological studies using hippocampal slices. \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> studies in rodents included receptor occupancy (ro) using a selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 tracer (autoradiography), pharmacological mri, and electroencephalography (eeg). alogabat was evaluated for its effects on the repetitive behavior phenotype in btbr and contactin-associated protein-like 2 (cntnap2\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup>) knockout mice, seizure models, cognitive performance in rats, and rotarod performance following combination treatment with diazepam.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">\u003cb>results:\u003c/b> alogabat is a potent positive allosteric modulator of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptors, with binding and functional selectivity. receptor occupancy studies provided direct proof of dose-dependent target engagement. functional circuit modulation was demonstrated by dose-dependent regional perfusion changes in pharmacological mri and changes in eeg theta- and beta-band power in rats. at &#x0003e;50% gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor occupancy, alogabat normalized elevated self-grooming behavior in both cntnap2\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup> and btbr mice and exhibited antiepileptic activity in rats. alogabat did not impair cognition in wildtype rats at gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 receptor occupancy up to 75%, although impairment occurred at higher doses, probably due to increased activity at other receptor subtypes and/or saturation of &#x003b1;5 receptors. alogabat did not worsen diazepam-induced impairment on the rotarod test.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">\u003cb>conclusion:\u003c/b> alogabat showed beneficial effects in mouse models relevant to neurodevelopmental disorders and anti-seizure activity at doses that did not produce cognitive, sedative, or motoric side effects.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"clear\">\u003c/div>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"journalfulltext\">\u003ca id=\"h2\" name=\"h2\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>1 introduction\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">alterations in the gabaergic system, the main inhibitory neurotransmitter system in the brain, may contribute to the pathophysiology of neurodevelopmental disorders (ndds), such as autism spectrum disorder (asd) and angelman syndrome (as). asd is a complex, heterogeneous ndd with both genetic and environmental factors (\u003ca href=\"#b7\">bourgeron, 2015\u003c/a>) contributing to aberrant changes in brain growth, neuronal development, and functional connectivity (\u003ca href=\"#b18\">dhossche et al., 2002\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b55\">pizzarelli and cherubini, 2011\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b8\">braat and kooy, 2015\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b58\">robertson et al., 2016\u003c/a>). asd is characterized by two core domains: impairments in social interaction and communication and the presence of repetitive or restricted behaviors, interests, or activities (\u003ca href=\"#b3\">american psychiatric association, 2008\u003c/a>). there are a range of comorbid conditions, including irritability, depression, anxiety, attention deficits, obsessive-compulsive symptoms, seizures, and sleep disruption. as is a rare genetic ndd with a prevalence of 1 in 12,000 to 20,000 births (\u003ca href=\"#b38\">luk and lo, 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b44\">mertz et al., 2013\u003c/a>). individuals with as often present with autistic features, severe intellectual disability, microcephaly, speech impairment, bursts of laughter, sleep problems, movement disorders, and epilepsy (\u003ca href=\"#b12\">buiting, 2010\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b35\">kalsner and chamberlain, 2015\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors are ligand-gated chloride channels. there are 19 genes encoding gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor subunits that assemble as pentamers, with the most common stoichiometry being two &#x003b1;, two &#x003b2;, and one &#x003b3; subunit. gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> subunit combinations give rise to functional, circuit, and behavioral specificity (\u003ca href=\"#b65\">sieghart, 2006\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b73\">vithlani et al., 2011\u003c/a>). gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors that contain the &#x003b1;5 subunit (gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5) are of particular interest due to their restricted pattern of expression and unique physiological and pharmacological properties (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">sur et al., 1999\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b46\">mohler, 2011\u003c/a>). in humans, gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptors containing the &#x003b1;5 subunit are preferentially localized in the hippocampus, prefrontal cortex, nucleus accumbens, amygdala, insular cortex, anterior cingulate, and cingulate cortex&#x02014;key regions believed to be involved in the neuropathology and pathophysiology of asd (\u003ca href=\"#b42\">mendez et al., 2013\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b48\">myers et al., 2017\u003c/a>). the \u003cem>gabra5\u003c/em> gene has been proposed as a candidate gene for asd (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">delong, 2007\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b45\">mesbah-oskui et al., 2017\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b74\">warrier et al., 2013\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b19\">di nanni et al., 2019\u003c/a>), suggesting decreased gabaergic inhibition in a subpopulation of autistic individuals. mutations involving the gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor subunit genes \u003cem>gabra5\u003c/em>, \u003cem>gabrb3\u003c/em>, and \u003cem>gabrg3\u003c/em> (encoding the &#x003b1;5, &#x003b2;3, and &#x003b3;3 subunits) found on chromosomal region 15q11&#x02013;q13 have been associated with ndds including as, epilepsy, and prader&#x02013;willi syndrome in addition to asd (\u003ca href=\"#b32\">hogart et al., 2010\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b61\">sanders, 2015\u003c/a>). as is predominantly caused by the loss of function of the maternally inherited \u003cem>ube3a\u003c/em> gene; however, approximately 75% of individuals with as carry a large deletion of the maternal 15q11&#x02013;q13 chromosomal region. clinical studies have shown that individuals with as who have large deletions (deletion as) exhibit more severe symptoms than those in whom \u003cem>ube3a\u003c/em> is the only gene affected, suggesting that the \u003cem>gabra5\u003c/em>, \u003cem>gabrb3\u003c/em>, and \u003cem>gabrg3\u003c/em> genes are relevant to the etiology of the disease.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">imaging studies using pet and magnetic resonance spectroscopy have shown reduced gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor binding in the superior and medial frontal cortex (\u003ca href=\"#b47\">mori et al., 2012\u003c/a>) and reduced gaba levels in individuals with asd (\u003ca href=\"#b58\">robertson et al., 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b28\">gaetz et al., 2014\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b59\">rojas et al., 2014\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b57\">puts et al., 2017\u003c/a>). postmortem studies have shown reduced numbers of inhibitory interneurons (\u003ca href=\"#b20\">dufour et al., 2023\u003c/a>), reduced expression of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor subunits (\u003ca href=\"#b16\">delorey, 2005\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b1\">abrahams and geschwind, 2008\u003c/a>), and reduced levels of the gaba-synthesizing enzymes such as glutamic acid decarboxylase (gad) 65 and 67 (\u003ca href=\"#b21\">fatemi et al., 2002\u003c/a>). there is increasing evidence from genetic, environmental, and phenotypic rodent models relevant to asd indicating that gabaergic circuit dysfunctions contribute to autism-like phenotypes (\u003ca href=\"#b27\">fukuda et al., 2005\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b13\">chao et al., 2010\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b6\">banerjee et al., 2013\u003c/a>). such deficits may result from multiple causes, including a reduced number of gabaergic interneurons, altered interneuron function, impaired gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor trafficking to the membrane, reduced expression of gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor subunits, and reduced gaba uptake function of gat-1 in neurons (\u003ca href=\"#b49\">nakamura et al., 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b50\">orefice et al., 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b43\">mermer et al., 2021\u003c/a>). supportive evidence is provided by the observation of autism-like behaviors in both gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 and &#x003b2;3 subunit knockout mice (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">zurek et al., 2016\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b17\">delorey et al., 2008\u003c/a>). regarding possible therapeutic approaches, enhancement of the gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> receptor activity by non-selective benzodiazepines has been shown to ameliorate autism-like behavioral deficits in mouse models; however, due to sedation that is likely mediated by the activation of the gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;1 subtype, very narrow therapeutic margins were observed (\u003ca href=\"#b30\">han et al., 2012\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b29\">han et al., 2014\u003c/a>; \u003ca href=\"#b37\">lim et al., 2017\u003c/a>). interestingly, a recent study showed that a gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 positive allosteric modulator (pam), sh-053-2&#x02032;f-r-ch3, attenuated social and cognitive deficits in male rats exposed to valproic acid \u003cem>in utero\u003c/em>, a rat model relevant to autism (\u003ca href=\"#b68\">souza et al., 2024\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">the aim of the current study was to determine whether a selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub>-&#x003b1;5 pam, alogabat (also known as ro7017773 or rg7816), would produce beneficial effects in animal models relevant to autism-like repetitive behavior&#x02014;specifically btbr mice (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">mcfarlane et al., 2008\u003c/a>) and contactin-associated protein-like 2 [cntnap2\u003csup>&#x02212;/&#x02212;\u003c/sup>] homozygous knockout mice (\u003ca href=\"#b51\">penagarikano et al., 2011\u003c/a>)&#x02014;and anti-seizure activity, without the typical side effects of non-selective gaba\u003csub>a\u003c/sub> pams, such as sedation and cognitive impairment. furthermore, target engagement was assessed by \u003cem>in vivo\u003c/em> receptor occupancy (ro) and pharmacological mri (phmri) in rodents, and an electroencephalography (eeg) study in rats was undertaken to identify a putative pharmacodynamic readout for future clinical trials.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h3\" name=\"h3\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>2 materials and methods\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">further information for each method listed below can be found in the \u003ca href=\"#sm1\">supplementary material\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h3-1\" name=\"h3-1\">\u003c/a>\u003ch3 class=\"pt0\">2.1 materials\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">alogabat [ro7017773; c\u003csub>21\u003c/sub>h\u003csub>23\u003c/sub>n\u003csub>5\u003c/sub>o\u003csub>4\u003c/sub>; 6-((5-methyl-3-(6-methylpyridin-3-yl)isoxazol-4-yl) methoxy)-n-(tetrahydropyran-4-yl)pyridazine-3-carboxamide (iupac name); molecular weight: 409.44&#x000a0;gmol\u003csup>&#x02212;1\u003c/sup>] was synthesized at f.hoffmann-la roche ag, switzerland [\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure 1a\u003c/a>; see example 8 in \u003ca href=\"#b10\">buettelmann et al., 2018\u003c/a>]. the discovery of alogabat and the related chemical series will be disclosed in future publications. diazepam, l-655,708, [\u003csup>3\u003c/sup>h]flumazenil, [\u003csup>3\u003c/sup>h]l-655,708, and [\u003csup>3\u003c/sup>h]ro0154513 were synthesized at f.hoffmann-la roche ag, switzerland.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">figure 1\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\u003ca
